facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1957 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 19 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated March 7, 1956 of PEPSU High Court in Criminal Revision No. 45 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 7, 1956, of the former PEPSU High Court in Criminal Revision No. 45 of 1956, arising out of the judgment

facts.text: Criminal Revision No. 45 of 1956 arose out of judgment dated February 22, 1956 of Additional Sessions Judge, Patiala in Criminal Appeal No. 175/36 of 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: , arising out of the judgment and order dated February 22, 1956, of the Additional Sessions Judge, Patiala, in Criminal Appeal No. 175/36 of 1955-56. Pritam Singh Safe, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant Pritam Singh was Sub-Inspector of Police and Station House Officer in-charge of Shehna police station in PEPSU State.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was a sub-Inspector of Police who at the relevant time was the Station House Officer in-charge Shehna police station in the erstwhile PEPSU State.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under s. 193 Indian Penal Code by First Class Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyvicted under s. 193, Indian Penal Code, by a First Class Magistrate and his appeal to the Sessions Judge, Patiala, was dismissed

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge Patiala dismissed except as to sentence.

anchor.surface_text: and his appeal to the Sessions Judge, Patiala, was dismissed except as to sentence. He took a revision to the PEPSU High Court but that was also dismissed.

facts.text: Revision to PEPSU High Court dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: He took a revision to the PEPSU High Court but that was also dismissed. This appeal has arisen in the following circumstances One Surjit Singh, s o Risaldar Waryam Singh,

facts.text: Surjit Singh s/o Risaldar Waryam Singh arrested on September 25, 1953 at Barnala in PEPSU State by Police Inspector Jaswant Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has arisen in the following circumstances One Surjit Singh, s o Risaldar Waryam Singh, was arrested on September 25, 1953, at Barnala in PEPSU State by the Police Inspector Jaswant Singh.

facts.text: Surjit Singh kept in lock-up at Barnala and on following day custody handed over to appellant, taken to Shehna police station lock-up.

anchor.surface_text: He was kept in the lock-up at Barnala and on the following day his custody was handed over to the appellant and he was taken to Shehna and was kept in custody-it is number clear under what section-in the police station lock- up at Shehna.

facts.text: Surjit Singh kept in custody at Shehna from September 26, 1953 till October 10, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Surjit Singh was there kept in custody from September 26, 1953, till October 10, 1953, when at about 10 p.m., he was surreptitiously removed to Police Station Dialpur

facts.text: On October 10, 1953 at about 10 p.m., Surjit Singh removed to Police Station Dialpur, then to Police Post Hamirgarh, then to Police Station Baga Purana in Ferozepur District, Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: , when at about 10 p.m., he was surreptitiously removed to Police Station Dialpur and then to Police Post Hamirgarh and from there was taken to Police Station Baga Purana in Ferozepur District, of the then Punjab.

facts.text: Application under s.491 CrPC and Art.226 Constitution for writ of Habeas Corpus and Mandamus made in PEPSU High Court alleging unlawful custody without charge or remand.

anchor.surface_text: An application under s. 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code and under Art. 226 of the Constitution was made for a writ of Habeas Corpus and Mandamus in the High Court of PEPSU. In that petition it was alleged that Surjit Singh was being kept in unlawful custody without any charge being made and without obtaining a remand by a Magistrate.

facts.text: Appellant filed affidavit dated October 13, 1953 denying custody of Surjit Singh, stating he had association with notorious dacoits, was absconding, not arrested, not entrusted by Jaswant Singh.

anchor.surface_text: In reply to this, an affidavit dated October 13, 1953, was filed by the appel. lant in which he stated that Surjit Singh had association with numberorious dacoits that he, the appellant, had never taken him into custody at any time that the said Surjit Singh was absconding and had number been arrested in spite of the best efforts of the police that at the time of the making of the affidavit he was number in the appellants custody and that it was incorrect that Inspector Jaswant Singh had ever entrusted Surjit Singh to his  appellants  custody.

facts.text: Affidavit affirmed: facts in paras 1 to 7 true to best knowledge and belief, nothing relevant kept back.

anchor.surface_text: He also stated that numberpetition had been brought to him number had he received any telegram in companynection with the custody of Surjit Singh. This affidavit was affirmed as follows- I solemnly affirm that the facts stated from paras Nos. I to 7 are true to the best of my knowledge and belief and numberhing which is relevant to this case has been kept back from this Honble Court .

facts.text: Both parties admitted before High Court that Surjit Singh was not in custody of appellant; petition dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: As both the parties admitted before the High Court that Surjit Singh was number in the custody of the appellant the petition was dismissed.

facts.text: On November 9, 1953, brother of Surjit Singh made application under s.476 CrPC for prosecution of Jaswant Singh and appellant for perjury under s.193 IPC for false affidavits.

anchor.surface_text: On November 9, 1953, the brother of Surjit Singh made an application under s. 476, Criminal Procedure Code, for the prosecution of Inspector Jaswant Singh and the appellant for perjury under s. 193, Indian Penal Code, in that they had filed false affidavits.

facts.text: Another Judge of PEPSU High Court ordered prosecution of appellant and directed Registrar to file complaint.

anchor.surface_text: This matter was heard by another learned Judge of that Court who ordered the prosecution of the appellant and directed the Registrar of the High Court to file a companyplaint which was filed.

facts.text: First Class Magistrate at Patiala took cognizance of complaint, convicted appellant under s.193 IPC, sentenced to 9 months imprisonment and fine Rs.300, default 2 months SI.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint was taken companynizance of by the First Class Magistrate at Patiala who companyvicted the appellant and sentenced him to nine months imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 300/- and in default to undergo simple imprisonment for two months.

facts.text: Appeal to Sessions Judge Patiala: conviction confirmed, sentence reduced to 3 months SI and fine Rs.50, default 1 month SI.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the Sessions Judge, Patiala, who companyfirmed the order of companyviction but reduced the sentence to one of three months simple imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 50 and in default one months simple imprisonment,

facts.text: Revision against Sessions Judge order dismissed in limine by Chief Justice of PEPSU High Court.

anchor.surface_text: a revision against this order was dismissed in limine by the Chief Justice although he gave reasons for dismissing it. The appellant then obtained special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Appellant obtained special leave from Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then obtained special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Court finds appellant was legally bound to file affidavit and state truth under s.191 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said therefore that in the present case the appellant was number legally bound to place facts and circumstances before the Court to justify the detention of Surjit Singh and, this companyld be done by an affidavit.

facts.text: Deputy Registrar of PEPSU High Court authorised to administer oath; administered to appellant.

That officer as a witness for the prosecution has stated that he companyld administer an oath

issues.text: Whether the appellant could be convicted under s.193 IPC for false affidavit even though he was not bound to file one, as his case fell under s.191 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant the first contention raised was that the appellant was not bound to file an affidavit and therefore he could not be convicted under s. 193, Indian Penal Code, because his case did not fall under s. 191, Indian Penal Code. In support of his contention he relied upon the Rules

issues.text: Whether the Deputy Registrar of the High Court of PEPSU was authorised to administer oaths for the affidavit?
Whether affirming the affidavit as true 'to the best of knowledge and belief' precludes liability under s.193 IPC?
Whether the Magistrate was required to examine the complainant or hold a preliminary enquiry under ss.200 and 202 CrPC when the complaint was filed by the court under s.476 CrPC?

arguments.claim: The appellant was not bound to file an affidavit and therefore could not be convicted under s.193 IPC because his case did not fall under s.191 IPC

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant the first contention raised was that the appellant was not bound to file an affidavit and therefore he could not be convicted under s. 193, Indian Penal Code, because his case did not fall under s. 191, Indian Penal Code. In support of his contention he relied upon the Rules

arguments.court_reasoning: In Habeas Corpus where facts disputed, affidavit required to justify detention; Oaths Act ss.4,5,14 authorize and bind to truth; s.191 applies to statements on oath even if voluntary

arguments.claim: The Deputy Registrar of the High Court of PEPSU was not authorised to administer oaths
arguments.court_reasoning: Deputy Registrar testified he could administer oath as authorized officer

arguments.claim: Affidavit affirmed to best of knowledge and belief so cannot identify knowledge vs belief parts, precluding s.193 IPC liability
arguments.court_reasoning: All 7 paras state facts to appellant's knowledge; Explanation 2 to s.191 covers false belief as false evidence; Emperor v. Lachmi Narain not good law

arguments.claim: Magistrate erred by not examining complainant or holding preliminary enquiry under ss.200 and 202 CrPC on court complaint under s.476 CrPC
arguments.court_reasoning: Proviso (a) to s.200 exempts examination of court complainant; neither s.200 nor s.202 requires preliminary enquiry for court complaints

holdings.text: Whenever a man makes a statement in court on oath he is bound to state the truth and if he does not, he makes himself liable under the provisions of s. 193.

anchor.surface_text: Whenever a man makes a statement in court on oath he is bound to state the truth and if he does not, he makes himself liable under the provisions of s. 193. It is no defence to say that he was not bound to enter the witness-box. A defendant or even a plaintiff is not bound to go into the witness-box but if either of them chooses to do so he cannot, after he has taken the oath to make a truthful statement, state anything which is false.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Habeas Corpus with disputed facts, detaining authority must justify by affidavit; Oaths Act ss.4,5,14 authorize High Court officers to administer oath and bind deponent to truth; s.191 IPC applies to voluntary sworn statements.

holdings.text: That officer as a witness for the prosecution has stated that he could administer an oath and therefore this contention of the appellant is also without any force and must be repelled.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Deputy Registrar testified to his authority under Oaths Act s.4 to administer oaths as High Court officer.

holdings.text: We have read the affidavit which consists of 7 paragraphs and each paragraph relates to affirmation of a fact which, if true, could only be so to the appellants knowledge. But even belief would fall under Explanation 2 to s. 191.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affidavit paragraphs affirm facts within appellant's knowledge; Explanation 2 to s.191 IPC deems false statement of belief as false evidence; prior case law disregarded.

holdings.text: That contention is equally untenable because under s. 200, proviso (a) it is not necessary for a Magistrate when a complaint is made by a court to examine the complainant and neither s. 200 nor s. 202 requires a preliminary enquiry.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso (a) to s.200 CrPC exempts examination of court complainant; no preliminary enquiry under s.200 or s.202 required for court complaints under s.476 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: As has been pointed out in Greene v. Home Secretary 1 which was a case under Reg. 18-B of the Defence of the 1 1942 A.C. 284, 302. Realm Act the whole object of proceedings for a writ of Habeas Corpus is to make them expeditious, to keep them as free from technicality as possible and to keep them as simple as possible. The incalculable value of Habeas Corpus is that it enables the immediate determination of the right to the appellants freedom Lord Wright

precedents.cited_proposition: object of Habeas Corpus proceedings is to make them expeditious, free from technicality, and simple

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily an affidavit may number be necessary in making the return if the detention is under orders of the detaining authority in exercise of its plenary discretion as in Liversidge v. Anderson 1 and in Greenes case 2 or a person is detained under the orders of a Court. But where the detention is, as it was in the present case, it becomes necessary for the detaining authority to justify its action by disclosing facts which would show to the satisfaction of the Court that the custody is number impro- per.

precedents.cited_proposition: affidavit may not be necessary for return if detention under detaining authority's plenary discretion

anchor.surface_text: as in Liversidge v. Anderson 1 and in Greenes case 2 or a person is detained under the orders of a Court. But where the detention is, as it was in the present case, it becomes necessary for the detaining authority to justify its action by disclosing facts which would show to the satisfaction of the Court that the custody is number impro- per. Where the prisoner says I do number know why I have been detained, I have done numberwrong , it is for the detaining authority to justify the custody.

precedents.cited_proposition: affidavit may not be necessary for return if detention under detaining authority's plenary discretion

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied upon a judgment of the Allahabad High Court in Emperor v. Lachmi Narain 1 . But unless there was something peculiar in the facts of that case it cannot be companysidered to be good law. It does number even take into companysideration Explanation 2 of S. 191. Lastly it was urged that the procedure adopted by the Magistrate was erroneous in that he did number hold an enquiry as required under ss. 200 and 202, Criminal Procedure Code, the former of which is expressly mentioned in sub-section 2 of s. 476, Criminal Procedure Code.

outcome.relief_summary: All contentions of the appellant repelled; conviction under s. 193 IPC and sentence upheld
